message_1:
What is the change in enthalpy (ΔHrxn) of the following reaction at 25°C given the standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) of the reactants and products:
2SO2(g) + O2(g) -> 2SO3(g)
where:
ΔHf°(SO2(g)) = -296.84 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(O2(g)) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(SO3(g)) = -395.71 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔHrxn) for the given reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔHrxn = Σ [ΔHf°(products)] - Σ [ΔHf°(reactants)]

For the products, we have 2 moles of SO3(g), so we multiply the ΔHf°(SO3(g)) by 2:

ΔHf°(2SO3(g)) = 2 * (-395.71 kJ/mol) = -791.42 kJ/mol

For the reactants, we have 2 moles of SO2(g) and 1 mole of O2(g), so we multiply the ΔHf°(SO2(g)) by 2 and add the ΔHf°(O2(g)):

ΔHf°(2SO2(g) + O2(g)) = 2 * (-296.84 kJ/mol) + 0 kJ/mol = -593.68 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔHrxn = (-791.42 kJ/mol) - (-593.68 kJ/mol)

ΔHrxn = -791.42 kJ/mol + 593.68 kJ/mol

ΔHrxn = -197.74 kJ/mol

The change in enthalpy (ΔHrxn) for the given reaction at 25°C is -197.74 kJ/mol.
